review.title: Turing Test for the Internet of Things
review.abstract: How smart is your kettle? How smart are things in your kitchen, your house, your neighborhood, on the internet? With the advent of Internet of Things, and the move of making devices `smart' by utilizing AI, a natural question arrises, how can we evaluate the progress. The standard way of evaluating AI is through the Turing Test. While Turing Test was designed for AI; the device that it was tailored to was a computer. Applying the test to variety of devices that constitute Internet of Things poses a number of challenges which could be addressed through a number of adaptations.

sections.heading: II. SIMPLIFIED TURING TEST FOR THE INTERNET OF THINGS
sections.text: Let us propose a simple adaptation of the TT to the IOT, followed by a description of the challenges the test would face (in Section IV we propose extensions of the TT that would make it possible to alleviate at least some of the challenges).In this version, we strive to make as few changes as possible to the original test. Therefore, we only change the medium through which the "entertainment" takes place by replacing the computer terminal with a "thing" (e.g. an electric kettle (Figure 2).To add the I / O capabilities, we add a remote on / off control (which controls the on / off switch) to the kettle (similar to the keyboard in Thear Xiv: 141 2.38 02v1 [cs. sections.heading: III. CHALLENGES FOR TURNING TEST IN THE CONTEXT
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: OF THE INTERNET OF THINGS
sections.text: Turing Test was a truly visionary work that became a standard for assessing the performance of AI systems, six years before the official establishment of the Artificial Intelligence Unit [2]. However, in 1950, it was difficult to foresee any future developments that would affect the development of AI. In this section, we describe various aspects of the Internet of Things that make it difficult to apply TT easily.

sections.heading: A. Limited Interface
sections.text: The Turning Test assumes that the interaction takes place in text conversation format. Many of the things that define IOT have limited interfaces; for example, a kettle has only one on / off switch.

sections.heading: B. Limited Computational Capabilities
sections.text: Many of the IOT devices have limited computing capabilities, which are often aimed at very specific purposes (e.g. automatic shutdown of the control of the kettle).Intelligent behavior that is not human behavior.The Turing test is a test of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior that is indistinguishable from that of a human being.However, one of the major drawbacks of the Turing test is that not all intelligent behavior is human (Figure 3).This is exacerbated when we consider that the test medium is not a text-based conversation (which many things do not function in Section III-A.).Below we outline some of the challenges that arise in the context of IOT.1 Analyzing large amounts of numerical data: Most people may have difficulty analyzing large amounts of numerical data (which many things are functionally unable to do).Investigating numerical values (especially without analytical tools).2) Response time: People may not be able to react as quickly as possible.

sections.heading: D. Evaluation Criteria
sections.text: Turing test evaluates conversation intelligence. However, it is not clear whether this criterion makes sense in another context; for example, is it appropriate to measure how "intelligent" a kettle is by having a conversation with it; what if it speaks well but does not work well as a kettle (begins to think about the meaning of life while deciding whether to boil the water)?

sections.heading: E. Multiple Participants
sections.text: Turning Test requires interaction with a single participant at a time (be it a human or a computer).Internet of Things, as the name suggests, requires multiple entities to be involved, so the challenge is to adopt Turing Test for multiple participants.

sections.heading: IV. PROPOSED APPROACHES
sections.text: In this section, we describe approaches to address the challenges of adopting the Turing test in the context of the Internet of Things (III).

sections.heading: A. Limited Interface
sections.text: As described in Section III-A, many of the things that make up IOT have limited interfaces; e.g., a kettle only has an on / off switch. It could be suggested that the original interface (e.g. on / off switch) could be used for binary encryption of a text conversation. Another option is to add an interface for a text conversation. However, even if the interface allows the textual conversation, other related challenges remain unanswered: Would the device be mathematically able to conduct an intelligent conversation (Section III-B), and is the conversation the appropriate method to evaluate the intelligence of a device (Section III-D). The answer to these questions could dictate the shape of the interface. sections.heading: D. Evaluation Criteria
sections.text: Turing test evaluates conversation intelligence. However, it is not clear whether this criterion makes sense in another context; for example, is it appropriate to measure how "intelligent" a kettle is by having a conversation with it; what if it speaks well but does not perform well as a kettle (begins to think about the meaning of life for an hour while deciding whether to boil the water)? On the other hand, the focus on assessing the operational performance of humans and computers does not necessarily reflect how "intelligent" the 4 thing is. Below, we suggest some of the approaches that could be used (in combination or independently). 1) Interaction intelligence: To overcome some of the operational speed capabilities of humans and computers (Section III-C), we can evaluate intelligence through a form of dialogue. However, the dialogue is not textual, but operational (Figure 4). Both the questioner and the participants can simulate the time stamps to control the flow of time.

sections.heading: E. Multiple Participants
sections.text: Turning Test requires interaction with a single participant at a given time (be it a human or a computer). Internet of Things assumes, as the name suggests, that several units are involved, so the challenge is to apply Turing Test to several participants. Assuming that several participants raise more questions about the evaluation: • collective / distributed intelligence • mixed groups - different devices - different types of units (people & non-people) • multiple assessment instances • many - many or many (e.g. one - many: one person who controls several things) • participating versus non-participating units (in judging) Naive approach would be to simply apply the one-sided version of the test to multiple objects and aggregate the results. More interesting approaches could be achieved by being a bit creative, e.g. mixing human-controlled things with computer-controlled etc.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: It has been more than 50 years since the Turing Test was proposed to evaluate artificial intelligence. TT has stood the test of time very well and is still by far the most widely used way of evaluating artificial intelligence. However, new attitudes, especially the Internet of Things, pose a challenge to the traditional definition of the Turing Test (Section III). We show that the Turing Test could be adapted to these new attitudes with some modifications (Section IV).
